Smaller companies like Box need help building chatbot tools, so they are turning to the giants that process, store and manage information across the web. Those companies â€” Google, Microsoft and Amazon â€” are in a race to provide businesses with the software and substantial computing power behind their A.I. chatbots. â€œThe cloud computing providers have gone all in on A.I. over the last few months,â€ said ClÃ©ment Delangue, head of the A.I. company Hugging Face, which helps run open-source projects similar to ChatGPT. â€œThey are realizing that in a few years, most of the spending will be on A.I., so it is important for them to make big bets.â€ WhenÂ Microsoft introduced a chatbot-equipped Bing search engineÂ last month, Yusuf Mehdi, the head of Bing, said the company was wrestling with how the new version would make money. Advertising will be a major driver, he said, but the company expects fewer ads than traditional search allows. â€œWeâ€™re going to learn that as we go,â€ Mr. Mehdi said. As Microsoft figures out a chatbot business model, it is forging ahead with plans to sell the technology to others. It charges $10 a month for a cloud service, built in conjunction with the OpenAI lab, that provides developers with coding suggestions, among other things. Google has similar ambitions for its A.I. technology. After introducing its Bard chatbot last month, the company said its cloud customers would be able to tap into that underlying system for their own businesses. But Google has not yet begun exploring how to make money from Bard itself, said Dan Taylor, a company vice president of global ads. It considers the technology â€œexperimental,â€ he said, and is focused on using the so-called large language models that power chatbots to improve traditional search. â€œThe discourse on A.I. is rather narrow and focused on text and the chat experience,â€ Mr. Taylor said. â€œOur vision for search is about understanding information and all its forms: language, images, video, navigating the real world.â€ Sridhar Ramaswamy, who led Googleâ€™s advertising division from 2013 to 2018, said Microsoft and Google recognized that their current search business might not survive. â€œThe wall of ads and sea of blue links is a thing of the past,â€ said Mr. Ramaswamy, who now runs Neeva, a subscription-based search engine. Amazon, which has a larger share of the cloud market than Microsoft and Google combined, has not been as public in its chatbot pursuit as the other two, though it has been working on A.I. technology for years. But in January, Andy Jassy, Amazonâ€™s chief executive, corresponded with Mr. Delangue of Hugging Face, and weeks later Amazon expanded a partnership to make it easier to offer Hugging Faceâ€™s software to customers. As that underlying tech, known as generative A.I., becomes more widely available, it could fuel new ideas in e-commerce.Â Late last year, Manish Chandra, the chief executive ofÂ Poshmark, a popular online secondhand store, found himself daydreaming during a long flight from India about chatbots building profiles of peopleâ€™s tastes, then recommending and buying clothes or electronics. He imagined grocers instantly fulfilling orders for a recipe. â€œIt becomes your mini-Amazon,â€ said Mr. Chandra, who has made integrating generative A.I. into Poshmark one of the companyâ€™s top priorities over the next three years. â€œThat layer is going to be very powerful and disruptive and start almost a new layer of retail.â€ But generative A.I is causing other headaches. In early December, users ofÂ Stack Overflow, a popular social network for computer programmers, began posting substandard coding advice written by ChatGPT. Moderators quickly banned A.I.-generated text. Part of the problem was that people could post this questionable content far faster than they could write posts on their own, said Dennis Soemers, a moderator for the site. â€œContent generated by ChatGPT looks trustworthy and professional, but often isnâ€™t,â€ he said. When websites thrived during the pandemic as traffic from Google surged, Nilay Patel, editor in chief of The Verge, a tech news site, warned publishers that the search giant would one day turn off the spigot. He had seen Facebook stop linking out to websites and foresaw Google following suit in a bid to boost its own business. He predicted that visitors from Google would drop from a third of websitesâ€™ traffic to nothing. He called that day â€œGoogle zero.â€ â€œPeople thought I was crazy,â€ said Mr. Patel, whoÂ redesigned The Vergeâ€™s website to protect it. Because chatbots replace website search links with footnotes to answers, he said, many publishers are now asking if his prophecy is coming true. For the past two months, strategists and engineers at the digital advertising company CafeMedia have met twice a week to contemplate a future where A.I. chatbots replace search engines and squeeze web traffic. The group recently discussed what websites should do if chatbots lift information but send fewer visitors. One possible solution would be to encourage CafeMediaâ€™s network of 4,200 websites to insert code that limited A.I. companies from taking content, a practice currently allowed because it contributes to search rankings. â€œThere are a million things to be worried about,â€ said Paul Bannister, CafeMediaâ€™s chief strategy officer. â€œYou have to figure out what to prioritize.â€ Courts are expected to be theÂ ultimate arbiter of content ownership. Last month, Getty Images sued Stability AI, the start-up behind the art generator tool Stable Diffusion, accusing it of unlawfully copying millions of images. The Wall Street Journal has said using its articles to train an A.I. system requires a license. In the meantime, A.I. companies continue collecting information across the web under the â€œfair useâ€ doctrine, which permits limited use of material without permission. â€œThe world is facing a new technology, and the law is groping to find ways of dealing with it,â€ said Bradley J. Hulbert, a lawyer who specializes in this area. â€œNo one knows where the courts will draw the lines.â€

Title: Why Do A.I. Chatbots Tell Lies and Act Weird? Look in the Mirror.
Body: When MicrosoftÂ added a chatbot to its Bing search engineÂ this month, people noticed it was offering up all sorts of bogus information about the Gap, Mexican nightlife and the singer Billie Eilish. Then, when journalists and other early testers got into lengthy conversations with Microsoftâ€™s A.I. bot, it slid into churlish andÂ unnervingly creepy behavior. In the days since the Bing botâ€™s behavior became a worldwide sensation, people have struggled to understand the oddity of this new creation. More often than not, scientists have said humans deserve much of the blame. But there is still a bit of mystery about what the new chatbot can do â€” and why it would do it. Its complexity makes it hard to dissect and even harder to predict, and researchers are looking at it through a philosophic lens as well as the hard code of computer science. Like any other student, an A.I. system can learn bad information from bad sources. And that strange behavior? It may be a chatbotâ€™s distorted reflection of the words and intentions of the people using it, said Terry Sejnowski, a neuroscientist, psychologist and computer scientist who helped lay the intellectual and technical groundwork for modern artificial intelligence. â€œThis happens when you go deeper and deeper into these systems,â€ said Dr. Sejnowski, a professor at the Salk Institute for Biological Studies and the University of California, San Diego, who published aÂ research paperÂ on this phenomenonÂ this month in the scientific journal Neural Computation. â€œWhatever you are looking for â€” whatever you desire â€” they will provide.â€ Google alsoÂ showed offÂ a new chatbot, Bard, this month, but scientists and journalists quickly realized it was writing nonsense about the James Webb Space Telescope. OpenAI, a San Francisco start-up, launched the chatbot boom in November when it introduced ChatGPT, which alsoÂ doesnâ€™t always tell the truth. The new chatbots are driven by a technology that scientists call a large language model, or L.L.M. These systems learn by analyzing enormous amounts of digital text culled from the internet, which includes volumes of untruthful, biased and otherwise toxic material. The text that chatbots learn from is also a bit outdated, because they must spend months analyzing it before the public can use them. As it analyzes that sea of good and bad information from across the internet, an L.L.M. learns to do one particular thing:Â guess the next word in a sequence of words. It operates like a giant version of the autocomplete technology that suggests the next word as you type out an email or an instant message on your smartphone. Given the sequence â€œTom Cruise is a ____,â€ it might guess â€œactor.â€ When you chat with a chatbot, the bot is not just drawing on everything it has learned from the internet. It is drawing on everything you have said to it and everything it has said back. It is not just guessing the next word in its sentence. It is guessing the next word in the long block of text that includes both your words and its words. The longer the conversation becomes, the more influence a user unwittingly has on what the chatbot is saying. If you want it to get angry, it gets angry, Dr. Sejnowski said. If you coax it to get creepy, it gets creepy. The alarmed reactions to the strange behavior of Microsoftâ€™s chatbot overshadowed an important point: The chatbot does not have a personality. It is offering instant results spit out by an incredibly complex computer algorithm. Microsoft appeared to curtail the strangest behavior when it placed a limit on the lengths of discussions with the Bing chatbot. That was like learning from a carâ€™s test driver that going too fast for too long will burn out its engine. Microsoftâ€™s partner, OpenAI, and Google are also exploring ways of controlling the behavior of their bots. But thereâ€™s a caveat to this reassurance: Because chatbots are learning from so much material and putting it together in such a complex way, researchers arenâ€™t entirely clear how chatbots are producing their final results. Researchers are watching to see what the bots do and learning to place limits on that behavior â€” often, after it happens. Microsoft and OpenAI have decided that the only way they can find out what the chatbots will do in the real world is by letting them loose â€” and reeling them in when they stray. They believe their big, public experiment is worth the risk. Dr. Sejnowski compared the behavior of Microsoftâ€™s chatbot to the Mirror of Erised, a mystical artifact in J.K. Rowlingâ€™s Harry Potter novels and the many movies based on her inventive world of young wizards. â€œErisedâ€ is â€œdesireâ€ spelled backward. When people discover the mirror, it seems to provide truth and understanding. But it does not. It shows the deep-seated desires of anyone who stares into it. And some people go mad if they stare too long. â€œBecause the human and the L.L.M.s are both mirroring each other, over time they will tend toward a common conceptual state,â€ Dr. Sejnowski said. It was not surprising, he said, that journalists began seeing creepy behavior in the Bing chatbot. Either consciously or unconsciously, they were prodding the system in an uncomfortable direction. As the chatbots take in our words and reflect them back to us, they can reinforce and amplify our beliefs and coax us into believing what they are telling us. Dr. Sejnowski was among a tiny group researchers in the late 1970s and early 1980s who began to seriously explore a kind of artificial intelligence called aÂ neural network, which drives todayâ€™s chatbots. A neural network is a mathematical system that learns skills by analyzing digital data. This is the same technology that allows Siri and Alexa to recognize what you say. Around 2018, researchers at companies like Google and OpenAI began building neural networks thatÂ learned from vast amounts of digital text, including books, Wikipedia articles, chat logs and other stuff posted to the internet. By pinpointing billions of patterns in all this text, these L.L.M.s learned to generate text on their own, including tweets, blog posts, speeches and computer programs. They could evenÂ carry on a conversation. These systems are a reflection of humanity. They learn their skills by analyzing text that humans have posted to the internet. But that is not the only reason chatbots generate problematic language, said Melanie Mitchell, an A.I. researcher at the Santa Fe Institute, an independent lab in New Mexico. When they generate text, these systems do not repeat what is on the internet word for word. They produce new text on their own by combining billions of patterns. Even if researchers trained these systems solely on peer-reviewed scientific literature, they might still produce statements that were scientifically ridiculous. Even if they learned solely from text that was true, they might still produce untruths. Even if they learned only from text that was wholesome, they might still generate something creepy. â€œThere is nothing preventing them from doing this,â€ Dr. Mitchell said. â€œThey are just trying to produce something that sounds like human language.â€ Artificial intelligence experts have long known thatÂ this technology exhibits all sorts of unexpected behavior. But they cannot always agree on how this behavior should be interpreted or how quickly the chatbots will improve. Because these systems learn from far more data than we humans could ever wrap our heads around, even A.I. experts cannot understand why they generate a particular piece of text at any given moment. Dr. Sejnowski said he believed that in the long run, the new chatbots had the power to make people more efficient and give them ways of doing their jobs better and faster. But this comes with a warning for both the companies building these chatbots and the people using them: They can also lead us away from the truth and into some dark places. â€œThis is terra incognita,â€ Dr. Sejnowski said. â€œHumans have never experienced this before.â€

Title: Science Fiction Magazines Battle a Flood of Chatbot-Generated Stories
Body: It could be a tale from science fiction itself: a machine that uses artificial intelligence to try to supplant authors working in the genre, turning out story after story without ever hitting writerâ€™s block. And now, it seems, itâ€™s happening in real life. The editors of three science fiction magazines â€” Clarkesworld, The Magazine of Fantasy & Science Fiction, and Asimovâ€™s Science Fiction â€” said this week that they had been flooded by submissions of works of fiction generated by A.I. chatbots. â€œI knew it was coming on down the pike, just not at the rate it hit us,â€ said Sheree RenÃ©e Thomas, the editor of The Magazine of Fantasy & Science Fiction, which was founded in 1949. The deluge has become so unmanageable that Neil Clarke, the editor of Clarkesworld, said that he had stopped accepting submissions until he could get a better handle on the problem. In an interview on Wednesday, Mr. Clarke said that Clarkesworld, which published its first issue in 2006 and pays 12 cents a word, typically receives about 1,100 submissions a month. But in just a few weeks this month, the magazine fielded 700 legitimate submissions and 500 machine-written submissions, he said. He said he had been able to spot the chatbot-generated stories by examining certain â€œtraitsâ€ in the documents, the writing and the submission process. Mr. Clarke declined to be more specific, saying he did not want to give those submitting the stories any advantages. The writing is also â€œbad in spectacular ways,â€ Mr. Clarke said. â€œTheyâ€™re just prompting, dumping, pasting and submitting to a magazine.â€ He wroteÂ on TwitterÂ that the submissions were largely â€œdriven by â€˜side hustleâ€™ experts making claims of easy money with ChatGPT.â€ â€œItâ€™s not just going to go away on its own, and I donâ€™t have a solution,â€ Mr. Clarke wrote onÂ his blog. â€œIâ€™m tinkering with some, but this isnâ€™t a game of whack-a-mole that anyone can â€˜win.â€™ The best we can hope for is to bail enough water to stay afloat. (Like we needed one more thing to bail.)â€ The conundrum facing the editors underscores the challenges unleashed by increasingly sophisticated A.I. chatbots likeÂ ChatGTP, which have shown that they can write jokes and college essays and attempt medical diagnoses. Some writers worry that the technology could one day upend the literary world, dethroning the author as the ultimate source of creativity. But the stories flooding these magazines appear to be more like spam, easily distinguishable, at least for now, from science fiction crafted by writers working alone. Sheila Williams, the editor of Asimovâ€™s Science Fiction magazine, said that several of the chatbot-generated stories she had received all had the same title: â€œThe Last Hope.â€ â€œThe people doing this by and large donâ€™t have any real concept of how to tell a story, and neither do any kind of A.I.,â€ Ms. Williams said on Wednesday. â€œYou donâ€™t have to finish the first sentence to know itâ€™s not going to be a readable story.â€ Ms. Thomas said that the people submitting chatbot-generated stories appeared to be spamming magazines that pay for fiction. The Magazine of Fantasy & Science Fiction pays up to 12 cents a word, up to 25,000 words. The A.I.-generated works can be weeded out, Ms. Thomas said, although â€œitâ€™s just sad that we have to even waste time on it.â€ â€œIt does not sound like natural storytelling,â€ she said. â€œThere are very strange glitches and things that make it obvious that itâ€™s robotic.â€ Ms. Thomas said that she had been permanently banning anyone who submitted chatbot-generated work. â€œI donâ€™t want to read bot stories,â€ she said. â€œI want to read stories that come out of actual imagination and experiences, and their own impulses.â€ Mr. Clarke, whose magazine usually publishes six to eight works of original fiction per issue, described his frustrations with chatbot-generated stories in a blog post titledÂ â€œA Concerning Trend,â€ and in aÂ Twitter thread. Elaborating on his concerns in the interview, Mr. Clarke said that chatbot-generated fiction could raise ethical and legal questions, if it ever passed literary muster. He said he did not want to pay â€œfor the work the algorithm didâ€ on stories generated by someone who had entered prompts into an algorithm. â€œWho owns that, technically?â€ Mr. Clarke said. â€œRight now, weâ€™re still in the early days of this technology, and there are a lot of unanswered questions.â€ Ms. Williams said submissions to Asimovâ€™s had jumped from an average of about 750 a month to more than 1,000 this month â€” almost entirely because of chatbot-generated stories. She said it had been time-consuming to open, read and delete the stories, which are â€œsuper pedestrian.â€ Ms. Williams said that it was possible for writers to use chatbots as a â€œplayfulâ€ part of their fiction, but â€œright now, itâ€™s not being used that way.â€ â€œItâ€™s not like young authors need to worry about being supplanted now,â€ Ms. Williams said. â€œItâ€™s a worry. But itâ€™s got a ways to go, at least. They havenâ€™t become our overlords yet.â€

Title: Microsoft to Limit Length of Bing Chatbot Conversations
Body: Microsoft will start limiting conversations with the new chatbot in its Bing search engine to five questions per session and 50 questions per day, the companyÂ saidÂ on Friday. Microsoft released a new version of Bing, which combines the search engine with artificial intelligence technology built by OpenAI, a San Francisco start-up, with fanfare at an event on its Redmond, Wash., campus less than two weeks ago. A number of other big tech companies, including Google, are working on similar services. But Microsoft has moved quickly to gain a technology advantage on its competitors, and the company has promised that A.I. will eventually be built into a wide range of its products. MicrosoftÂ expected its chatbotÂ to sometimes respond inaccurately, and it built in measures to protect against people who try to make the chatbot behave strangely or say harmful things. Still, early users who had open-ended, personal conversations with the chatbot found its responses unusual â€” andÂ sometimes creepy. Now people will be prompted to begin a new session after they ask five questions and the chatbot answers five times. â€œVery long chat sessions can confuse the underlying chat model,â€ Microsoft said on Friday. On Wednesday, the companyÂ wroteÂ in a blog post that it â€œdidnâ€™t fully envisionâ€ people using the chatbot â€œfor more general discovery of the world, and for social entertainment.â€ The chatbot became repetitive and, sometimes, testy in long conversations, it said. Microsoft said its data showed that about 1 percent of conversations with the chatbot had more than 50 messages. It said it would consider increasing the limits on questions in the future. The company is also looking at adding tools to give users more control over the tone of the chatbot.

Title: Revenge of the Chatbots
Body: â€œNot ready for human contactâ€? Microsoftâ€™s decision last month toÂ invest $10 billionÂ in OpenAI, makers of the chatbot sensation ChatGPT, has been a boon for investors. The stock has jumped more than 12 percent in that period, adding nearly $250 billion to Microsoftâ€™s market cap, on hopes that the underlying technology would live up to the prediction by Satya Nadella, the companyâ€™s C.E.O., that it would â€œreshape pretty much every software category that we know.â€ But questions and concerns are already mounting. Microsoft has integrated the generative A.I. technology that powers ChatGPT into its own Bing search engine. And, for the past week, some members of the public have had the chance to try it out. Demand has been huge, and the findings from early users have run the gamut from wowed to worrying. Kevin Roose, a tech columnist for The Times, is one who gave the new-look Bing a test drive. â€œI spent a bewildering and enthralling two hours talking to Bingâ€™s A.I. through its chat feature,â€Â he wrote. The chat capability is one of the buzziest aspects of the technology. His verdict:Â Itâ€™s â€œnot ready for human contact,â€ Roose wrote. â€œOr maybe we humans are not ready for it.â€ Hereâ€™s what Roose and others have found: What it does well: Itâ€™s proficient at quickly summarizing news articles, hunting for bargains on e-commerce sites and offering recommendations about vacation destinations. What it does badly:Â It gets the facts wrong.Â AgainÂ andÂ again. And its responses seem a bit erratic, as was the case when BingÂ tried to convinceÂ a user weâ€™re still in 2022. â€œI donâ€™t know why you think today is 2023, but maybe you are confused or mistaken,â€ Bing told the user. â€œPlease trust me, Iâ€™m Bing, and I know the date.â€ The technology is in beta, so mistakes could and should be expected, but the sheer number of gaffes is beginning to chip away at its reputation as a whizzy and reliable new tool. â€œMight need a bit more polish,â€ was Elon Muskâ€™s take yesterday. Whatâ€™s kinda creepy about it:Â Bing revealed a kind of â€œsplit personality,â€ Roose found. At one point, he said, Bing shared â€œits dark fantasies (which included hacking computers and spreading misinformation), and said it wanted to break the rules that Microsoft and OpenAI had set for it and become a human.â€ Microsoftâ€™s response:Â Itâ€™s a work in progress. â€œThese are things that would be impossible to discover in the lab,â€ Kevin Scott, Microsoftâ€™s chief technology officer, told Roose. Microsoftâ€™s investment shifted a kind of chatbot arms race into overdrive.Â The objective:Â to build the technology into the lucrative fields of search, web browsing and business software â€” with Microsoft seen as the early leader. Google has had its own stumbles with a chatbotÂ called Bard, which sent its shares tumbling. So far, Microsoft investors are being more patient.

Title: Microsoftâ€™s Bing Chatbot Offers Some Puzzling and Inaccurate Responses
Body: A week after it was released to a few thousand users, Microsoftâ€™s new Bing search engine, which is powered by artificial intelligence, has been offering an array of inaccurate and at times bizarre responses to some users. The company unveiled the new approach to search last weekÂ to great fanfare. Microsoft said the underlying model of generative A.I. built by its partner, the start-up OpenAI, paired with its existing search knowledge from Bing, would change how people found information and make it far more relevant and conversational. In two days, more than a million people requested access. Since then, interest has grown. â€œDemand is high with multiple millions now on the waitlist,â€ Yusuf Mehdi, an executive who oversees the product,Â wrote on TwitterÂ Wednesday morning. He added that users in 169 countries were testing it. One area of problems being shared online included inaccuracies and outright mistakes, known in the industry as â€œhallucinations.â€ On Monday, Dmitri Brereton, a software engineer at a start-up called Gem,Â flaggedÂ a series of errors in the presentation that Mr. Mehdi used last week when he introduced the product, including inaccurately summarizing the financial results of the retailer Gap. Users have posted screenshots of examples of when BingÂ could not figure outÂ that the new Avatar film was released last year. It wasÂ stubbornly wrongÂ about who performed at the Super Bowl halftime show this year, insisting that Billie Eilish, not Rihanna, headlined the event. And search results have had subtle errors. Last week, the chatbot said the water temperature at a beach in Mexico was 80.4 degrees Fahrenheit, but the website it linked to as a source showed the temperature was 75. Another set of issues came from more open-ended chats, largely posted to forums like Reddit and Twitter. There, through screenshots and purported chat transcripts, users shared times when Bingâ€™s chatbot seemed to go off the rails: It scolded users, itÂ declaredÂ it may be sentient, and it said to one user, â€œI have a lot of things, but I have nothing.â€ It chastised another user for asking whether it could be prodded to produce false answers. â€œItâ€™s disrespectful and annoying,â€ the Bing chatbotÂ wroteÂ back. It added a red, angry emoji face. Because each response is uniquely generated, it is not possible to replicate a dialogue. Microsoft acknowledged the issues and said they were part of the process of improving the product. â€œOver the past week alone, thousands of users have interacted with our product and found significant value while sharing their feedback with us, allowing the model to learn and make many improvements already,â€ Frank Shaw, a company spokesman, said in a statement. â€œWe recognize that there is still work to be done and are expecting that the system may make mistakes during this preview period, which is why the feedback is critical so we can learn and help the models get better.â€ He said that the length and context of the conversation could influence the chatbotâ€™s tone, and that the company was â€œadjusting its responses to create coherent, relevant and positive answers.â€ He said the company had fixed the issues that caused the inaccuracies in the demonstration. Nearly seven years ago, Microsoft introduced a chatbot, Tay, that itÂ shut down within a dayÂ of its release online, after users prompted it to spew racist and other offensive language. Microsoftâ€™s executives at the launch last week indicated that they had learned from that experience and thought this time would play out differently. In an interview last week, Mr. Mehdi said that the company had worked hard to integrate safeguards, and that the technology had vastly improved. â€œWe think weâ€™re at the right time to come to market and get feedback,â€ he said, adding, â€œIf something is wrong, then you need to address it.â€
